Project Documentationïƒ

Main Project READMEïƒ

Yiâ€™s Module 1ïƒ

This repository demonstrates and compares two powerful dimensionality reduction methods implemented from scratch using Python:

  • ğŸ”¹ GraphDR â€“ a linear graph-regularized smoother for structured embedding

  • ğŸ”¹ t-SNE â€“ a non-linear, probabilistic method for manifold visualization

Both methods are applied to high-dimensional data like MNIST or single-cell datasets to explore geometry and clustering in low dimensions.

Graph-based dimensionality reduction using Laplacian smoothing + PCA

From-scratch PyTorch implementation of t-SNE with TensorBoard support

tsne/README.md

TSNE Moduleïƒ

Torch t-SNE on MNISTïƒ

This project provides a clean, from-scratch implementation of t-SNE (t-Distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding) using PyTorch. It demonstrates how to reduce high-dimensional data (like MNIST images) into 2D for visualization purposes.

Featuresïƒ

  • Manual computation of pairwise distances and probability matrices (P and Q)

  • Custom implementation of KL divergence as loss

  • Optimization via PyTorchâ€™s autograd and Adam optimizer

  • TensorBoard integration for:

    • Loss curves

    • 2D embedding visualization (projector tab)

  • Clean visualization of digit clusters in 2D

File Structureïƒ

â”œâ”€â”€ t-sne.py # Main script â”œâ”€â”€ tsne_mnist/ # TensorBoard logs and embeddings â”œâ”€â”€ raw/ # Downloaded MNIST dataset â””â”€â”€ README.md

Run the scriptïƒ

python t-sne.py

This will:

  • Download the MNIST dataset

  • Flatten the 28x28 images into 784-dimensional vectors

  • Run t-SNE to embed them into 2D space

  • Save TensorBoard visualizations

Launch TensorBoardïƒ

tensorboard --logdir=runs/tsne_mnist

Go to http://localhost:6006 to see:

  • The KL divergence curve

  • Embedding visualization under the â€œProjectorâ€ tab

tsne.Hbeta(D, beta=1.0)ïƒ

Compute entropy(H) and probability(P) from nxn distance matrix.

Dnumpy.ndarray

distance matrix (n,n)

betafloat

precision measure

\[eta =\]

rac{1}/{(2 * sigma^2)}

Hfloat

entropy

Pnumpy.ndarray

probability matrix (n,n)

tsne.adjustbeta(X, D, tol, perplexity)ïƒ

dichotomy search for the best beta Precision(beta) adjustment based on perplexity

Parameters:

  • X (numpy.ndarray) â€“ data input array with dimension (n,d)

  • tol (float) â€“ tolerance for the stopping criteria of beta adjustment

  • perplexity (float) â€“ perplexity can be interpreted as a smooth measure of the effective number of neighbors

Returns:

  • P (numpy.ndarray) â€“ probability matrix (n,n)

  • beta (numpy.ndarray) â€“ precision array (n,1)

tsne.compute_low_dim_similarities(Y)ïƒ

Compute low-dimensional similarities using t-distribution kernel.

Parameters:

Y â€“ 2D embeddings (n, d)

Returns:

Similarity matrix (n, n)

Return type:

Q

tsne.high_dim_similarity(X, perplexity=30.0, tol=1e-05)ïƒ

Compute high-dimensional pairwise similarities.

Parameters:

  • X â€“ Input tensor (n, d)

  • perplexity â€“ Effective neighborhood size

  • tol â€“ Search tolerance

Returns:

Symmetric similarity matrix (n, n)

Return type:

P

tsne.kl_divergence(P, Q)ïƒ

Compute Kullbackâ€“Leibler divergence between P and Q.

Parameters:

  • P â€“ Probability matrices (n, n)

  • Q â€“ Probability matrices (n, n)

Returns:

Scalar loss value

tsne.pairwise_distances(x)ïƒ

Compute squared Euclidean distances between rows of x.

Parameters:

x â€“ Tensor of shape (n, d)

Returns:

Tensor of shape (n, n) - distance matrix

tsne.plot_tsne_scatter(Y, labels)ïƒ

Plot a 2D scatter plot for t-SNE embeddings.

Parameters:

  • Y â€“ ndarray or Tensor of shape (N, 2) - 2D embeddings

  • labels â€“ ndarray or Tensor of shape (N,) - class labels

tsne.save_metadata_tsv(labels, filepath='runs/tsne_mnist/metadata.tsv')ïƒ

generate a tsv file to match the color and label

tsne.tsne(X, labels, n_components=2, perplexity=30.0, tol=1e-05, learning_rate=2.0, n_iter=1000)ïƒ

Run t-SNE on input tensor X.

Parameters:

  • X â€“ Input data (n, d)

  • labels â€“ Corresponding labels (n,)

  • n_components â€“ Target dimension (default: 2)

  • perplexity â€“ Controls local/global trade-off

  • tol â€“ Tolerance for beta search

  • learning_rate â€“ Optimizer learning rate

  • n_iter â€“ Number of optimization steps

Returns:

Numpy array of shape (n, n_components)

GraphDR Moduleïƒ

GraphDR Demonstrationïƒ

This repository contains a demonstration of the GraphDR algorithm, a linearized graph-based dimensionality reduction technique designed for structure-preserving visualization of high-dimensional data such as single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq).

GraphDR blends the strengths of PCA and graph smoothing into a unified framework for denoising and dimensionality reduction.

ğŸ“˜ Whatâ€™s in This Notebook?ïƒ

The GraphDR_test.ipynb notebook includes:

  • Construction of a k-NN graph from input data

  • Graph smoothing via linear system solving

  • Dimensionality reduction via PCA

  • Visualization of smoothed data

  • Example with MNIST or toy data (depending on your dataset)

ğŸ”§ Requirementsïƒ

You can install the dependencies using:

pip install numpy scipy scikit-learn matplotlib
